title: How to Become Free from Past Karmas? | Sri Madhu Pandit Dasa | SB 3.22.12 | 14.08.2024
speaker: HG Madhu Pandit Dasa

segments.key_quote: In material life, everyone is desirous of sense gratification.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the topic of detachment and sense gratification in material life.

segments.key_quote: Sukha Dukha, material Sukha Dukha for the body and the mind, is fixed for everybody when one takes birth.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that Sukha and Dukha (happiness and distress) are fixed at birth, but not in a way that eliminates free will.

segments.key_quote: Suppose there is a currency called Sukha currency. And there is another currency called Dukha currency.
segments.summary: The speaker uses the analogy of 'Sukha' and 'Dukha' currency to explain how these experiences are allotted at birth.

segments.key_quote: If the devotee is having the, you know, has determined to work hard for Prabhupada, take trouble for Prabhupada, sweat for Prabhupada, take tension for Prabhupada, take anxiety for Prabhupada, please understand that you are burning your Dukkha currency.
segments.summary: The speaker explains how devotees can manage pleasure and pain by using their 'currency' in Krishna's service, burning off 'Dukkha currency' through austerities.

segments.key_quote: So secret number one is, take authorized austerities.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of taking authorized austerities in Krishna consciousness to avoid struggling for material existence.

segments.key_quote: We should, body and mind should have austerity every day. Something you don't like, you will have to do every day.
segments.summary: The speaker advises devotees to incorporate daily austerities into their lives, focusing on overcoming their default tendencies in service.

segments.key_quote: No, we are talking about tapasya which will give us eternal benefit.
segments.summary: The speaker cautions against generalized austerities and emphasizes the importance of performing austerities that are pleasing to Vishnu.

segments.key_quote: Srila Prabhupada has given us, even within these bona fide austerities, again a set of austerities.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that even within bona fide austerities, there are specific guidelines given by the spiritual master, using the example of visiting Radha Kunda.

segments.key_quote: In fact, the greatest tapasya that one can do in this age is to hear the holy name of the Lord.
segments.summary: The speaker highlights that hearing the holy name of the Lord is the greatest tapasya in this age, despite being easier than other forms of austerity.

segments.key_quote: That is why an Acharya's guidance is required. Otherwise you will misunderstand.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the need for an Acharya's guidance to properly understand the scriptures and apply them to one's life.

segments.key_quote: You can decide what to take pleasure in, you have got a free will.
segments.summary: The speaker shifts the focus to managing pleasure, emphasizing that individuals have the free will to choose what they take pleasure in.

segments.key_quote: Take pleasure in every work that you do for Prabhupada and Krishna.
segments.summary: The speaker advises devotees to take pleasure in chanting, devotional service, and all work done for Krishna to manage their pleasure quota.

segments.key_quote: You can take pleasure in a painful thing.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that one can even take pleasure in painful things, especially when done in service to Krishna, and that the mood in which service is done is important.

segments.key_quote: At the same time we don't get bound by karma. In the same time, if we are freed from sinful expressions of pain and pleasure.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses managing pleasure and pain to avoid karma, emphasizing bona fide expressions of pleasure in Krishna consciousness.

segments.key_quote: Because pleasure is a combination of something from outside and your decision to enjoy.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that pleasure is a combination of external stimuli and the individual's decision to enjoy, highlighting the role of free will.

segments.key_quote: So we have to take pleasure in bona fide expressions of pleasure, which are many in Krishna consciousness movement, authorized for us as a Brahmachari, as a Grihastha, whatever, it is plenty.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by emphasizing the importance of managing pleasure and pain through authorized means in Krishna consciousness to achieve a peaceful mind.

segments.key_quote: Yes, it manages, because two things you are already doing, taking pleasure in chanting, and while taking pleasure in chanting, you are doing austerity with your mind and body, which doesn't take pleasure.
segments.summary: In a Q&A, the speaker explains how chanting nicely manages pleasure and pain by combining the soul's pleasure with the body and mind's austerity.

segments.key_quote: Unless purity comes, full purity comes, we cannot be a Dheera always.
segments.summary: The speaker clarifies that while full purity is needed to be a 'Dheera' (sober) always, devotees can achieve it on a day-to-day basis by following the instructions of pure devotees.

segments.key_quote: You have to chant more, you have to do another 10-15 years of service, then I will give you this answer.
segments.summary: In a Q&A, the speaker jokingly deflects a complex question about how material energy captured a soul from Vaikuntha.

segments.key_quote: You've got a free will to take pleasure in pain of body and mind.
segments.summary: In a Q&A, the speaker clarifies that while the body and mind experience pain and pleasure, the soul has the free will to take pleasure even in the pain of the body and mind.
